facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 89-93 of 1964 are appeals by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 89--93 of 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated August 30, 1961

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and orders dated August 30, 1961 and June 13, 1961 in Special Civil Application Nos. 440, 441, 509, 510 and 7 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated August 30, 1961 and June 13, 1961 in Special Civil Application Nos. 440, 441,509, 510 and 7 of 1961.

facts.text: These five appeals raise a common question of interpretation of r. 19 of the Displaced Persons Compensation Rehabilitation Rules, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: These five appeals by special leave raise a companymon question of interpretation of r. 19 of the Displaced Persons  Compensation Rehabilitation  Rules, 1955  hereinafter referred to as the Rules .

facts.text: Respondent Lachman Hotchand Kriplani is a displaced person from West Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Lachman Hotchand Kriplani, is a displaced person from West Pakistan.

facts.text: Lachman Hotchand Kriplani has three brothers.

anchor.surface_text: He has three brothers.

facts.text: They owned 731 acres of agricultural land in District Nawabshah, Taluka Nawab Shah, Sind--now in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: They owned 731 acres of agricultural land in District Nawabshah, Taluka Nawab Shah, Sind--now in Pakistan.

facts.text: Respondent submitted a claim under the Displaced Persons Claims Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted a claim under the Displaced Persons  Claims  Act, 1950  XLIV of 1950 --hereinafter referred to as the Claims Act.

facts.text: Respondent's claim was that he owned 1/4 share of 731 acres and 14 ghuntas standing in the name of Fatehchand.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents claim was that he owned 1/4 share of 731 acres and 14 ghuntas standing in the name, of Fatehehand.

facts.text: Claim Officer by order dated October 7, 1952 accepted the claim and assessed it as 94-3 standard acres.

anchor.surface_text: The Claim Officer, by order dated October 7, 1952, accepted the claim and assessed his claim as 94-3 standard acres.

facts.text: On July 2, 1955, respondent applied for compensation under the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act XLIV of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On July 2, 1955, the respondent applied for companypensation under the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Act  XLIV Of 1954

facts.text: In the application, respondent stated he was not a member of a Joint Hindu Family in Pakistan, but his claim was as a co-sharer along with three others who had filed separate claims.

anchor.surface_text: In the application he stated that he was number a member of a Joint Hindu Family in Pakistan, but his claim was as a companysharer alongwith three others, who had filed separate claims.

facts.text: Assistant Settlement Commissioner held enquiry and by order dated March 3, 1960 held that the four alleged co-sharers were members of a Joint Hindu Family, and the whole agricultural land claim was to be treated as joint property.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Settlement Commissioner was, however, number satisfied with this assertion and after holding an enquiry, by order dated March 3, 1960, he held that the four alleged companysharers were members of a Joint Hindu Family,

facts.text: On August 29, 1960, a statement of account was issued to the respondent showing his claim assessed as Rs. 10,701/- gross compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On August 29, 1960, a statement of account was issued to the respondent. This statement showed that his claim was assessed as Rs. 10,701/- gross companypensation.

facts.text: The claim was assessed for 376 standard acres and 12 units out of which the petitioner had 1/4th share.

anchor.surface_text: The claim was assessed for 376 standard acres and 12 units out of which the petitioner had 1/4th share.

facts.text: Compensation on 376 Standard Acres and 12 Units works out to 108 Standard Acres 0-3/10 Units as per scale in Rule 51, converted to Rs. 42,806/- per Rule 56; petitioner's 1/4th share Rs. 10,701/- .

anchor.surface_text: The companypensation on 376 Standard Acres and 12 Units works out to 108 Standard Acres 0-3/10 Units as per scale indicated in Rule 51. This companyverted in terms of money as per Rule 56 companyes to Rs. 42,806/- The petitioners 1/4th share would be Rs. 10,701/- .

facts.text: On October 28, 1960, respondent served notice on Regional Settlement Commissioner to rectify the statement of account.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then on October 28, 1960, served a numberice on the Regional Settlement Commissioner calling upon him to rectify the statement of account,

facts.text: In notice, respondent claimed r. 20 applied or alternatively r. 19.

anchor.surface_text: In this numberice he claimed that r. 20 applied to his case in the alternative he asserted that at least r. 19 should be applied to him.

facts.text: Assistant Settlement Commissioner replied that calculation was correct.

anchor.surface_text: In reply, the Assistant Settlement Commissioner informed him that the calculation had been done companyrectly.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under arts. 226 and 227 in Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, he filed a petition under arts. 226 and 227, in the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: High Court allowed the petition, set aside the statement of account of August 29, 1960, and directed application of r. 19.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the petition and set aside the statement of account furnished to the petitioner on August 29, 1960, and directed that the respondent shall give the benefit of r. 19 and determine the amount of companypensation payable to him

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave; appeals before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant having obtained special leave, the appeals are number before us.

facts.text: In High Court, respondent's counsel did not challenge the finding that respondent and brothers were members of joint family.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention at the outset that in the High Court the respondents companynsel did number challenge the finding of the Assistant Settlement Commissioner that the respondent and his brothers were members of a joint family.

facts.text: High Court held that r. 19 applied to agricultural land.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that r. 19 applied to agricultural land.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that r. 19 applies to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as member of Joint Hindu Family.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in agreement with the High Court, we hold that r. 19 will apply to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as a member of the Joint Hindu Family.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs; other appeals also fail.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts. As stated in the beginning, it is companymon ground that if this appeal fails the other appeals must also fail. They are accordingly dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: common question of interpretation of r. 19 of the Displaced Persons Compensation Rehabilitation Rules, 1955

anchor.surface_text: These five appeals by special leave raise a common question of interpretation of r. 19 of the Displaced Persons Compensation Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 hereinafter referred to as the Rules .

issues.text: whether r. 19 applied only to non-agricultural land

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the conclusion that r. 19 applied to agricultural land. It found nothing in the scheme of the Rules, or in the language of r. 19, to support the claim of the Department that r. 19 applied only to non-agricultural land.

issues.text: whether Chapter IV, in which r. 19 occurs, does not deal with agricultural lands at all

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must reject the contention that Chapter IV, in which r. 19 occurs, does not deal with agricultural lands at all.

arguments.claim: ss.4-8 do not distinguish between urban and agricultural verified claims

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with the 1955 Rules, it is apparent that ss. 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 do not in any manner distinguish between urban land and agricultural land as long as the agricultural land is the subject-matter of a verified claim.

arguments.claim: rr.12-15 in Chapter IV apply to agricultural verified claims

anchor.surface_text: Rule 12 directs the Regional Settlement Commissioner to consolidate all these papers. Rule 12 obviously applies to application in respect of verified claims to agricultural land.

arguments.claim: r.19 general words 'properties' and 'claim' include agricultural land

anchor.surface_text: The heading Special Provision for payment of compensation to joint families is general. So is sub-rule 1. The word properties is general and would include agricultural land. That this is the meaning is also borne out if we consider the word claim.

arguments.claim: no principle of construction limits scope of general words in r.19(1)

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General has not been able to point to any principle of construction which would enable us to limit the scope of the general words in r. 19(1).

arguments.claim: it would be height of inequity if r.20 not apply to ag land

anchor.surface_text: It would be the height of inequity to hold this.

arguments.claim: r.19 applies to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as member of Joint Hindu Family

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in agreement with the High Court, we hold that r. 19 will apply to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as a member of the Joint Hindu Family.

holdings.text: r. 19 will apply to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as a member of the Joint Hindu Family.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in agreement with the High Court, we hold that r. 19 will apply to the claim of the respondent in respect of agricultural land left by him as a member of the Joint Hindu Family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General language of r.19 includes 'properties' and 'claim'; ss.4-8 make no distinction for verified agricultural claims; Ch.IV rules like rr.12-15 apply to agricultural claims; no construction limits general words.

holdings.text: ss. 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 do not in any manner distinguish between urban land and agricultural land as long as the agricultural land is the subject-matter of a verified claim.

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with the 1955 Rules, it is apparent that ss. 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 do not in any manner distinguish between urban land and agricultural land as long as the agricultural land is the subject-matter of a verified claim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of ss.4-8 applies to verified claims without distinguishing urban from agricultural land; public dues deduction applies equally.

holdings.text: Chapter IV, in which r. 19 occurs, does deal with agricultural lands.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must reject the contention that Chapter IV, in which r. 19 occurs, does not deal with agricultural lands at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: rr.12-15 apply to verified agricultural claims; Appendix VII has column for agricultural land and remarks on r.19.

holdings.text: r. 20 applies to a claim in respect of agricultural land.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General, when asked, said that even r. 20 would not apply to a claim in respect of agricultural land, but we are unable to accede to this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.20 provides for co-owners generally; excluding agricultural land would be height of inequity; distinguishes unit determination (Ch.IV) from payment mode (Ch.VIII).

holdings.text: No principle of construction limits the scope of the general words in r. 19(1).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General has not been able to point to any principle of construction which would enable us to limit the scope of the general words in r. 19(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heading and sub-r.1 general; 'properties' and 'claim' include agricultural land per textual meaning and application form.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs; the other appeals must also fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs. As stated in the beginning, it is common ground that if this appeal fails the other appeals must also fail. They are accordingly dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of holding on r.19 to facts; common question in all appeals.
